main_definition: A group of people living in the same area or having a particular characteristic in common.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Social unit: A community refers to a group of people who live in the same geographical area, often sharing common interests and values. Example: The residents of Springfield come together regularly for neighborhood clean-up events.
meanings_and_examples.example: The farming community relies on cooperation among its members.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Online community: A group of individuals who interact with each other through the internet, often sharing information or ideas. Example: The online forum for video game enthusiasts is a vibrant virtual community.
meanings_and_examples.example: The tech support team fosters an online community where users can ask questions and share solutions.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Community of practice: A group of people who share a profession or interest, regularly engaging in discussion and learning. Example: The local gardening club is a community of practice for green thumbs.
meanings_and_examples.example: A software development company encourages its employees to join the coding community.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Religious community: A group of people who share common beliefs and worship practices, often within a specific faith. Example: The Buddhist sangha is considered a religious community.
meanings_and_examples.example: The members of the monastery are part of a monastic spiritual community.

meanings_and_examples.definition: Working community: A group of professionals collaborating towards a common goal or project, often within an organization. Example: The marketing team forms a working community to launch a new product.
meanings_and_examples.example: The research and development department works as a scientific community.
